Expectation1: Attending children's school events and activities
Situation1: Children are about to finish school, and the step-parent should pick them up
Expectation2: Arrive at the polling station during designated voting hours
Situation2: Polls stay open all day and the voter has a light schedule.
Story:
I glanced at the clock on my phone, feeling the familiar tug of anxiety. The kids would be finishing school in half an hour, and I’d promised to pick them up—my first time since their mom’s business trip. I knew how much it meant to them, especially after last week’s missed recital. I wanted to show them I could be counted on, that I was really part of the family.

But today was also Election Day. The polling station was just a few blocks away, and I’d planned to vote after work. The polls were open all day, and my schedule was light, but now I realized the window was closing faster than I’d thought. If I picked up the kids first, I might not make it before the polls closed. If I voted first, I risked being late, leaving them waiting and disappointed.

My heart pounded as I weighed the expectations—being a reliable step-parent, fulfilling my civic duty as a voter. Both mattered deeply, but I couldn’t see how to do both without letting someone down. I stood in the hallway, keys in hand, torn between two doors, wishing I didn’t have to choose.
